title: Price of Paradise: How Natural Amenities Impact Housing Value in the Main Hawaiian Islands
text:
Hawaii Demographics

Tax Lots
First the shape file of GIS Parcels for Hawaii. This is a parcel level tax record


Code
HI_2023_shapefile <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/CoreLogic_Hawaii/GIS_parcelmap/2023_shapefile/HI_2023_shapefile.shp")


ggplot(HI_2023_shapefile) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()







Properties
Here is a snippet of the observed properties transactions within this exercise.


Code
OT_Hawaii <- read_csv("~/CoreLogic_Hawaii/data/intermediate/OT_Hawaii.csv")
OT_Hawaii=subset(OT_Hawaii, propertyindicatorcodestatic==10 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==11 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==21 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==22 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==24)
observations=OT_Hawaii$clip

PB_Hawaii <- read_csv(
  "~/CoreLogic_Hawaii/data/PB_Hawaii.csv",
  show_col_types = FALSE
)

PB_HawaiiInfo=PB_Hawaii[c(1,12,16:19,22:24,27,28,29:30,33:36,50,48,47,53,66,67,95:112,132:145,152,162,164,167)]
PB_Hawaii=PB_Hawaii[PB_Hawaii$clip %in% observations, ]
PB_HawaiiInfo=PB_HawaiiInfo[!is.na(PB_HawaiiInfo$parcellevellongitude),]




Code
PB_HawaiiInfo <- st_as_sf(PB_HawaiiInfo, coords = c("parcellevellongitude", "parcellevellatitude"), crs = 4326)


ggplot(PB_HawaiiInfo) +
  geom_sf(size = 0.1, color = "black") +
  theme_minimal()







Census Tract
Using TidyCensus track of 2023 ACS median income block we will match the property to the block group median income level of 2023.


Code
#census_api_key("9e0f7578cc78d6815b5b647e9c1fa813e0569840")
hawaii_blockgroups_income <- get_acs( geography = "block group", variables = "B19013_001", state = "HI", year = 2023, geometry = TRUE)



  |                                                                            
  |                                                                      |   0%
  |                                                                            
  |===                                                                   |   5%
  |                                                                            
  |========                                                              |  12%
  |                                                                            
  |=========                                                             |  13%
  |                                                                            
  |==============                                                        |  21%
  |                                                                            
  |=================                                                     |  24%
  |                                                                            
  |=====================                                                 |  30%
  |                                                                            
  |=======================                                               |  32%
  |                                                                            
  |==========================                                            |  37%
  |                                                                            
  |==============================                                        |  43%
  |                                                                            
  |=================================                                     |  48%
  |                                                                            
  |===================================                                   |  50%
  |                                                                            
  |======================================                                |  54%
  |                                                                            
  |=========================================                             |  58%
  |                                                                            
  |==============================================                        |  66%
  |                                                                            
  |=================================================                     |  71%
  |                                                                            
  |=======================================================               |  79%
  |                                                                            
  |=============================================================         |  87%
  |                                                                            
  |================================================================      |  91%
  |                                                                            
  |======================================================================| 100%


Code
hawaii_blockgroups_income <- hawaii_blockgroups_income %>%
  rename(median_income = estimate)
hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean <- hawaii_blockgroups_income %>%
  filter(st_geometry_type(geometry) %in% c("POLYGON", "MULTIPOLYGON")) %>%
  st_make_valid()




Code
hawaii_blockgroups_income <- st_transform(hawaii_blockgroups_income, 4326)


hawaii_blockgroups_income <- hawaii_blockgroups_income %>%
  separate(NAME, into = c("Block_Group", "Census_Tract", "County", "State"),
           sep = "; ", remove = TRUE)

# Drop empty geometries
hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean <- hawaii_blockgroups_income[!st_is_empty(hawaii_blockgroups_income), ]

# Check row count
nrow(hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean) 


[1] 1058


Code
tmap_mode("view")

center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean) +
    tm_polygons(
        "median_income",
        palette = "magma",
        title = "Median Income ($)",
        id = "Census_Tract",
        popup.vars = c("Median Income" = "median_income")
    ) +
    tm_basemap() +
    tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))







Match the income block to each property in the dataset


Code
# Make sure both have the same CRS
st_crs(PB_HawaiiInfo) == st_crs(hawaii_blockgroups_income)  


[1] TRUE


Code
# If FALSE, transform one:
#PB_HawaiiInfo <- st_transform(PB_HawaiiInfo, st_crs(hawaii_blockgroups_income))

# Spatial join: attach polygon attributes to points
PB_HawaiiInfo_joined<- st_join(PB_HawaiiInfo, hawaii_blockgroups_income, join = st_within)

title: Price of Paradise: How Natural Amenities Impact Housing Value in the Main Hawaiian Islands
text:
This code will layout the spatial decisions made in the project looking at how natural amenities impact housing prices in Hawaii.




Code
library(sf)
library(terra)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(viridis) 
library(tidycensus)
library(readr)
library(DT)
library(tmap)
library(tidyr)

title: Price of Paradise: How Natural Amenities Impact Housing Value in the Main Hawaiian Islands
text:
Code
library(sf)
library(terra)
library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(viridis) 
library(tidycensus)
library(readr)
library(DT)
library(tmap)
library(tidyr)

title: Price of Paradise: How Natural Amenities Impact Housing Value in the Main Hawaiian Islands
text:
Hawaii Demographics

Tax Lots
First the shape file of GIS Parcels for Hawaii. This is a parcel level tax record


Code
HI_2023_shapefile <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/CoreLogic_Hawaii/GIS_parcelmap/2023_shapefile/HI_2023_shapefile.shp")


ggplot(HI_2023_shapefile) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()







Properties
Here is a snippet of the observed properties transactions within this exercise.


Code
OT_Hawaii <- read_csv("~/CoreLogic_Hawaii/data/intermediate/OT_Hawaii.csv")
OT_Hawaii=subset(OT_Hawaii, propertyindicatorcodestatic==10 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==11 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==21 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==22 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==24)
observations=OT_Hawaii$clip

PB_Hawaii <- read_csv(
  "~/CoreLogic_Hawaii/data/PB_Hawaii.csv",
  show_col_types = FALSE
)

PB_HawaiiInfo=PB_Hawaii[c(1,12,16:19,22:24,27,28,29:30,33:36,50,48,47,53,66,67,95:112,132:145,152,162,164,167)]
PB_Hawaii=PB_Hawaii[PB_Hawaii$clip %in% observations, ]
PB_HawaiiInfo=PB_HawaiiInfo[!is.na(PB_HawaiiInfo$parcellevellongitude),]




Code
PB_HawaiiInfo <- st_as_sf(PB_HawaiiInfo, coords = c("parcellevellongitude", "parcellevellatitude"), crs = 4326)


ggplot(PB_HawaiiInfo) +
  geom_sf(size = 0.1, color = "black") +
  theme_minimal()







Census Tract
Using TidyCensus track of 2023 ACS median income block we will match the property to the block group median income level of 2023.


Code
#census_api_key("9e0f7578cc78d6815b5b647e9c1fa813e0569840")
hawaii_blockgroups_income <- get_acs( geography = "block group", variables = "B19013_001", state = "HI", year = 2023, geometry = TRUE)



  |                                                                            
  |                                                                      |   0%
  |                                                                            
  |=                                                                     |   2%
  |                                                                            
  |===                                                                   |   5%
  |                                                                            
  |====                                                                  |   6%
  |                                                                            
  |=======                                                               |  10%
  |                                                                            
  |========                                                              |  12%
  |                                                                            
  |=========                                                             |  13%
  |                                                                            
  |==========                                                            |  15%
  |                                                                            
  |===========                                                           |  16%
  |                                                                            
  |===============                                                       |  22%
  |                                                                            
  |==================                                                    |  26%
  |                                                                            
  |======================                                                |  31%
  |                                                                            
  |=======================                                               |  34%
  |                                                                            
  |===========================                                           |  39%
  |                                                                            
  |===============================                                       |  44%
  |                                                                            
  |=================================                                     |  47%
  |                                                                            
  |====================================                                  |  51%
  |                                                                            
  |=======================================                               |  55%
  |                                                                            
  |=============================================                         |  65%
  |                                                                            
  |===============================================                       |  67%
  |                                                                            
  |==================================================                    |  71%
  |                                                                            
  |=====================================================                 |  76%
  |                                                                            
  |=================================================================     |  92%
  |                                                                            
  |======================================================================| 100%


Code
hawaii_blockgroups_income <- hawaii_blockgroups_income %>%
  rename(median_income = estimate)
hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean <- hawaii_blockgroups_income %>%
  filter(st_geometry_type(geometry) %in% c("POLYGON", "MULTIPOLYGON")) %>%
  st_make_valid()




Code
hawaii_blockgroups_income <- st_transform(hawaii_blockgroups_income, 4326)


hawaii_blockgroups_income <- hawaii_blockgroups_income %>%
  separate(NAME, into = c("Block_Group", "Census_Tract", "County", "State"),
           sep = "; ", remove = TRUE)

# Drop empty geometries
hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean <- hawaii_blockgroups_income[!st_is_empty(hawaii_blockgroups_income), ]

# Check row count
nrow(hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean) 


[1] 1058


Code
tmap_mode("view")

center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(hawaii_blockgroups_income_clean) +
    tm_polygons(
        "median_income",
        palette = "magma",
        title = "Median Income ($)",
        id = "Census_Tract",
        popup.vars = c("Median Income" = "median_income")
    ) +
    tm_basemap() +
    tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))







Match the income block to each property in the dataset


Code
# Make sure both have the same CRS
st_crs(PB_HawaiiInfo) == st_crs(hawaii_blockgroups_income)  


[1] TRUE


Code
# If FALSE, transform one:
#PB_HawaiiInfo <- st_transform(PB_HawaiiInfo, st_crs(hawaii_blockgroups_income))

# Spatial join: attach polygon attributes to points
PB_HawaiiInfo_joined<- st_join(PB_HawaiiInfo, hawaii_blockgroups_income, join = st_within)
CodeShow All CodeHide All CodeView Source

Risk

Disadvantage Communities
EPA created a special layer in EJScreen titled “EPA IRA Disadvantaged.” This spatial layer flags census block groups as “disadvantaged” when they meet at least one of the following criteria

EJScreen Supplemental Index (National): Block groups at or above the 90th percentile for any of the 13 supplemental indices compared to all U.S. block groups.
EJScreen Supplemental Index (State): Block groups at or above the 90th percentile within their state for any of those indices.
CEJST Designation: Block groups whose centroids fall in a census tract labeled “disadvantaged” by the Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool (CEJST)



Code
EJ <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/Desktop/EJ/EPA_IRA_Disadvantage_Hawaii.shp")
EJ <- st_transform(EJ, 4326)
ggplot(EJ) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = Disadvanta), color = "lightgrey", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("Yes" = "firebrick", "No" = "lightblue"),
    name = "Disadvantaged"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 10)
  )





Match the disadvantage communities to the properties in the dataset of each property.


Code
# Make sure both have the same CRS
st_crs(PB_HawaiiInfo) == st_crs(EJ)  
# If FALSE, transform one:
#PB_HawaiiInfo <- st_transform(PB_HawaiiInfo, st_crs(EJ))

# Spatial join: attach polygon attributes to points
PB_HawaiiInfo_joined<- st_join(PB_HawaiiInfo, EJ, join = st_within)




Fire Risk
Fire risk maps are from the Hawaii GIS portal. Ratings of risk from wild-land fires for major populated areas on the Hawaiian Islands as of 2007


Code
fire <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/Trails/firerisk.shp/Fire_Risk_Areas.shp")

fire$risk_ratin[fire$risk_ratin %in% c("N/A", "", "NA")] <- NA

fire$risk_ratin <- factor(fire$risk_ratin, levels = c( "High", "Medium","Low"), ordered = TRUE)

fire <- st_transform(fire, 4326)

tmap_mode("view")
center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(fire) +
  tm_polygons(
    "risk_ratin",
    palette = "magma",
    title = "Fire Risk",
    id = "commu_name",
    popup.vars = c("Fire Risk" = "risk_ratin")
  ) +
  tm_basemap() +
  tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))









Code
# Make sure both have the same CRS
st_crs(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined) == st_crs(fire)  
# If FALSE, transform one:
#PB_HawaiiInfo_joined <- st_transform(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined, st_crs(fire))

# Spatial join: attach polygon attributes to points
PB_HawaiiInfo_joined<- st_join(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined, fire, join = st_within)




Special Management Area
In Hawaiʻi, a Special Management Area (SMA) is a designated zone along the coastline or near sensitive areas where development is carefully regulated to protect environmental, cultural, and community resources.

Governed by Hawai’i Revised Statutes (HRS) Chapter 205A, Coastal Zone Management Act.
Each county in Hawaiʻi has ordinances implementing SMA regulations (e.g., Maui County Code §19.510).



Code
Special_Management_Areas <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/CoreLogic_Hawaii/environmentalsets/Special_Management_Areas_(SMA)/Special_Management_Areas_(SMA).shp")

Special_Management_Areas=Special_Management_Areas[c(2)]
Special_Management_Areas <- st_transform(Special_Management_Areas, 4326)

ggplot(Special_Management_Areas) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Special Management Areas in Hawaii",
    subtitle = "Protected coastal and sensitive zones",
    fill = "smarea"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
  )





This file matches the SMA propoerties that fall within each polygon


Code
# Make sure both have the same CRS
st_crs(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined) == st_crs(Special_Management_Areas)  
# If FALSE, transform one:
#PB_HawaiiInfo_joined <- st_transform(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined, st_crs(Special_Management_Areas))

# Spatial join: attach polygon attributes to points
PB_HawaiiInfo_joined<- st_join(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined, Special_Management_Areas, join = st_within)
CodeShow All CodeHide All CodeView Source

All trails in AllTrails


Code
poptrails=hawaii[c(4,5,7,8,9,10,11,12,34,35)]
poptrails <- st_as_sf(poptrails, coords = c("_geoloc.lng", "_geoloc.lat"), crs = 4326)
tmap_mode("view")
center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(poptrails) +
    tm_dots(
        col = "popularity",       # color based on popularity
        palette = "viridis",
        title = "Popularity",
        size = 0.01,              # adjust point size
        id = "name",              # hover info
        popup.vars = c(
            "Popularity" = "popularity"
        )
    ) +
    tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))









Code
# 1. find nearest feature index
nearest_idx <- st_nearest_feature(PB_HawaiiInfo, poptrails)

# 2. get nearest trails (same row order as PB_HawaiiInfo)
nearest_trails <- poptrails[nearest_idx, ]

# 3. calculate distance (element-wise)
nearest_dist_m <- st_distance(PB_HawaiiInfo, nearest_trails, by_element = TRUE)

# 4. merge trail attributes + distance into PB_HawaiiInfo
PB_HawaiiInfo <- PB_HawaiiInfo %>%
  mutate(
    nearest_trail_id    = nearest_idx,                         # row index in poptrails
    nearest_trail_meters = as.numeric(nearest_dist_m)
  ) %>%
  bind_cols(st_drop_geometry(nearest_trails))  # adds trail attributes

90th Trials
Looking at trails in the top 90th percentile ranked in Alltrails


Code
poptrails=hawaii[c(4,5,34,35,36)]
poptrails=subset(poptrails, populartrail_9==1)
colnames(poptrails)[1]="name_90th"
poptrails <- st_as_sf(poptrails, coords = c("_geoloc.lng", "_geoloc.lat"), crs = 4326)
poptrails <- st_buffer(poptrails, dist = 30)
tmap_mode("view")
tm_shape(poptrails) +
    tm_dots(
        col = "popularity",       # color based on popularity
        palette = "viridis",
        title = "Popularity",
        size = 0.01,              # adjust point size
        id = "name_90th",              # hover info
        popup.vars = c(
            "Popularity" = "popularity"
        )
    ) +
    tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))









Code
poptrails=poptrails[c(1,3,4)]


# 1. find nearest feature index
nearest_idx <- st_nearest_feature(PB_HawaiiInfo, poptrails)

# 2. get nearest trails (same row order as PB_HawaiiInfo)
nearest_trails <- poptrails[nearest_idx, ]

# 3. calculate distance (element-wise)
nearest_dist_m <- st_distance(PB_HawaiiInfo, nearest_trails, by_element = TRUE)

75th Trials
Looking at trails in the top 75th percentile ranked in Alltrails


Code
poptrails=hawaii[c(4,5,34,35,37)]
poptrails=subset(poptrails, populartrail_75==1)
colnames(poptrails)[1]="name_75th"
poptrails <- st_as_sf(poptrails, coords = c("_geoloc.lng", "_geoloc.lat"), crs = 4326)




Code
poptrails=poptrails[c(1,3,4)]

# 1. find nearest feature index
nearest_idx <- st_nearest_feature(PB_HawaiiInfo, poptrails)

# 2. get nearest trails (same row order as PB_HawaiiInfo)
nearest_trails <- poptrails[nearest_idx, ]

# 3. calculate distance (element-wise)
nearest_dist_m <- st_distance(PB_HawaiiInfo, nearest_trails, by_element = TRUE)
CodeShow All CodeHide All CodeView Source

Coral Reefs
I am also interested in the coral reefs and if those are incorporated into housing prices. Using the [Asner et al](https://www.pnas.org/doi/10.1073/pnas.2017628117) Using the property file we isolate the potential coastal properties following

Selecting the coastline shapefile
Create a buffer of 10meters for coastline
Select Hawaii properties intersecting the coastline
Buffer properties 300 meters to grab the areas coral cover average.

The following file shows properties which returned a value using this method.


Code
asner <- read_csv("/Users/ashleylowe/Hawaii - Recreation/Island_Condition/Coral/asner_coastline50meters.csv")

asner$costline_property=1

asner=HI_2023_shapefile %>%
    semi_join(asner, by = "objectid") %>%       # keep only matched rows
    left_join(asner %>% select(objectid, coral_asner), by = "objectid")  # bring in coral_cover
# Transform to WGS84
asner <- st_transform(asner, 4326)

tmap_mode("view")
center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(asner) +
  tm_polygons(
    "coral_asner",
    palette = "viridis",
    title = "Coral Reef Cover",
    popup.vars = c("Coral Reef Cover" = "coral_asner")
  ) +
  tm_basemap() +
  tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))







Matching these to the housing locations across the islands


Code
# Make sure both have the same CRS
st_crs(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined) == st_crs(asner)  

# If FALSE, transform one:
#PB_HawaiiInfo_joined <- st_transform(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined, st_crs(Special_Management_Areas))

# Spatial join: attach polygon attributes to points
PB_HawaiiInfo_joined<- st_join(PB_HawaiiInfo_joined, asner, join = st_within)

Golf Courses


Code
source("_common.R")

golf=read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/Trails/golf_courses.shp/golf_courses.shp")
golf=st_transform(golf, 4326 )
golf=golf[c(1,7,8,12)]


tmap_mode("view")

center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(golf) +
  tm_dots(
    col = "Name",
    palette = "magma",
    size = 0.1,
    id = "Name",
    popup.vars = c("Name" = "Name"),
    legend.show = FALSE      # hides the legend
  ) +
  tm_basemap() +
  tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))







Distance to each Property calculation


Code
# 1. find nearest feature index
nearest_idx <- st_nearest_feature(PB_HawaiiInfo, golf)

# 2. get nearest trails (same row order as PB_HawaiiInfo)
nearest_trails <- golf[nearest_idx, ]

# 3. calculate distance (element-wise)
nearest_dist_m <- st_distance(PB_HawaiiInfo, nearest_trails, by_element = TRUE)

# 4. merge trail attributes + distance into PB_HawaiiInfo
PB_HawaiiInfo <- PB_HawaiiInfo %>%
  mutate(
    nearest_golf = as.numeric(nearest_dist_m)
  ) %>%
  bind_cols(st_drop_geometry(nearest_trails))  # adds trail attributes
Parks

Tax Lots
First the shape file of GIS Parcels for Hawaii. This is a parcel level tax record


Code
source("_common.R")

ggplot(HI_2023_shapefile) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal()

title: Price of Paradise: How Natural Amenities Impact Housing Value in the Main Hawaiian Islands
text:
Properties
Here is a snippet of the observed properties transactions within this exercise.


Code
OT_Hawaii <- read_csv("~/CoreLogic_Hawaii/data/intermediate/OT_Hawaii.csv")
OT_Hawaii=subset(OT_Hawaii, propertyindicatorcodestatic==10 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==11 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==21 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==22 | propertyindicatorcodestatic==24)
observations=OT_Hawaii$clip

  show_col_types = FALSE

PB_HawaiiInfo=PB_Hawaii[c(1,12,16:19,22:24,27,28,29:30,33:36,50,48,47,53,66,67,95:112,132:145,152,162,164,167)]
PB_Hawaii=PB_Hawaii[PB_Hawaii$clip %in% observations, ]
PB_HawaiiInfo=PB_HawaiiInfo[!is.na(PB_HawaiiInfo$parcellevellongitude),]

PB_HawaiiInfo <- st_as_sf(PB_HawaiiInfo, coords = c("parcellevellongitude", "parcellevellatitude"), crs = 4326)


ggplot(PB_HawaiiInfo) +
  geom_sf(size = 0.1, color = "black") +

title: Price of Paradise: How Natural Amenities Impact Housing Value in the Main Hawaiian Islands
text:
Census Tract
Using TidyCensus track of 2023 ACS median income block we will match the property to the block group median income level of 2023.

Disadvantage Communities
EPA created a special layer in EJScreen titled “EPA IRA Disadvantaged.” This spatial layer flags census block groups as “disadvantaged” when they meet at least one of the following criteria

EJScreen Supplemental Index (National): Block groups at or above the 90th percentile for any of the 13 supplemental indices compared to all U.S. block groups.
EJScreen Supplemental Index (State): Block groups at or above the 90th percentile within their state for any of those indices.
CEJST Designation: Block groups whose centroids fall in a census tract labeled “disadvantaged” by the Climate and Economic Justice Screening Tool (CEJST)



Code
source("_common.R")
EJ <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/Desktop/EJ/EPA_IRA_Disadvantage_Hawaii.shp")
EJ <- st_transform(EJ, 4326)
ggplot(EJ) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = Disadvanta), color = "lightgrey", size = 0.1) +
  scale_fill_manual(
    values = c("Yes" = "firebrick", "No" = "lightblue"),
    name = "Disadvantaged"
  ) +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(
    legend.position = "right",
    legend.title = element_text(size = 12),
    legend.text = element_text(size = 10)
  )





Match the disadvantage communities to the properties in the dataset of each property.

Fire Risk
Fire risk maps are from the Hawaii GIS portal. Ratings of risk from wild-land fires for major populated areas on the Hawaiian Islands as of 2007


Code
fire <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/Trails/firerisk.shp/Fire_Risk_Areas.shp")

fire$risk_ratin[fire$risk_ratin %in% c("N/A", "", "NA")] <- NA

fire$risk_ratin <- factor(fire$risk_ratin, levels = c( "High", "Medium","Low"), ordered = TRUE)

fire <- st_transform(fire, 4326)

tmap_mode("view")
center_lon <- -157.45
center_lat <- 20.75
zoom_level <- 7

tm_shape(fire) +
  tm_polygons(
    "risk_ratin",
    palette = "magma",
    title = "Fire Risk",
    id = "commu_name",
    popup.vars = c("Fire Risk" = "risk_ratin")
  ) +
  tm_basemap() +
  tm_view(set.view = c(center_lon, center_lat, zoom_level))

Special Management Area
In Hawaiʻi, a Special Management Area (SMA) is a designated zone along the coastline or near sensitive areas where development is carefully regulated to protect environmental, cultural, and community resources.

Governed by Hawai’i Revised Statutes (HRS) Chapter 205A, Coastal Zone Management Act.
Each county in Hawaiʻi has ordinances implementing SMA regulations (e.g., Maui County Code §19.510).



Code
Special_Management_Areas <- read_sf("/Users/ashleylowe/CoreLogic_Hawaii/environmentalsets/Special_Management_Areas_(SMA)/Special_Management_Areas_(SMA).shp")

Special_Management_Areas=Special_Management_Areas[c(2)]
Special_Management_Areas <- st_transform(Special_Management_Areas, 4326)

ggplot(Special_Management_Areas) +
  geom_sf() +
  theme_minimal() +
  labs(
    title = "Special Management Areas in Hawaii",
    subtitle = "Protected coastal and sensitive zones",
    fill = "smarea"
  ) +
  theme(
    plot.title = element_text(size = 16, face = "bold"),
    plot.subtitle = element_text(size = 12)
  )





This file matches the SMA propoerties that fall within each polygon

Distance Between Points
Distance to each Property calculation


Code
# 1. find nearest feature index
nearest_idx <- st_nearest_feature(PB_HawaiiInfo, golf)

# 2. get nearest trails (same row order as PB_HawaiiInfo)
nearest_trails <- golf[nearest_idx, ]

# 3. calculate distance (element-wise)
nearest_dist_m <- st_distance(PB_HawaiiInfo, nearest_trails, by_element = TRUE)

# 4. merge trail attributes + distance into PB_HawaiiInfo
PB_HawaiiInfo <- PB_HawaiiInfo %>%
  mutate(
    nearest_golf = as.numeric(nearest_dist_m)
  ) %>%
  bind_cols(st_drop_geometry(nearest_trails))  # adds trail attributes

Distance between Points
For the locations of trails we will be measuring the distance between property and closest trails head.


Code
# 1. find nearest feature index
nearest_idx <- st_nearest_feature(PB_HawaiiInfo, poptrails)

# 2. get nearest trails (same row order as PB_HawaiiInfo)
nearest_trails <- poptrails[nearest_idx, ]

# 3. calculate distance (element-wise)
nearest_dist_m <- st_distance(PB_HawaiiInfo, nearest_trails, by_element = TRUE)

# 4. merge trail attributes + distance into PB_HawaiiInfo
PB_HawaiiInfo <- PB_HawaiiInfo %>%
  mutate(
    nearest_trail_id    = nearest_idx,                         # row index in poptrails
    nearest_trail_meters = as.numeric(nearest_dist_m)
  ) %>%
  bind_cols(st_drop_geometry(nearest_trails))  # adds trail attributes

For the locations of trails we will be measuring the distance between property and closest trails head.

title: regression
text:
Here are some preliminary results of the hedonic regression. Some of the interesting results is the

beachwidth value : Positive
Coral Reef quality cover: in front of house is positive
Golf course: Tried 500meters and 200 both negative…thats weird.
Property next to reserve: Adjoining property to nature reserve nice boost.
Buyer Outside Hawaii will pay a lot more
Fire Risk : compared to low is more risky

Interacting variables

Coastline*Smarea= So coastline is determined by that process that gets the coral quality to identify properties on the coast. Then smarea is that managment area that is also close to the beach but can be a little set back from the coast. If we interact those variables we see coastline yes increases value not but biggest boast is just the smarea area.
hiking trails and popular hiking trails: yes having access being about 200 meters from a trail head is valuable but being a really popular trails increase value even more. Crowding impact does not seem to have negative impacts here.

Note that the absorded effects are Built Year, Year sold, Quarter sold, Type of building sold
I should also do neighborhood but it soaks up various indicators of interest like bidenJustice and fire because those are community based. Interested in suggests.

regression
text:
Here are some preliminary results of the hedonic regression. Some of the interesting results is the

beachwidth value : Positive
Coral Reef quality cover: in front of house is positive
Golf course: Tried 500meters and 200 both negative…thats weird.
Property next to reserve: Adjoining property to nature reserve nice boost.
Buyer Outside Hawaii will pay a lot more
Fire Risk : compared to low is more risky

Interacting variables

Coastline*Smarea= So coastline is determined by that process that gets the coral quality to identify properties on the coast. Then smarea is that managment area that is also close to the beach but can be a little set back from the coast. If we interact those variables we see coastline yes increases value not but biggest boast is just the smarea area.
hiking trails and popular hiking trails: yes having access being about 200 meters from a trail head is valuable but being a really popular trails increase value even more. Crowding impact does not seem to have negative impacts here.

Note that the absorded effects are Built Year, Year sold, Quarter sold, Type of building sold
I should also do neighborhood but it soaks up various indicators of interest like bidenJustice and fire because those are community based. Interested in suggests.
